Article 50 seems to specify transparency obligations for deployers:   1. of  "an emotion recognition system or a biometric categorisation system", and/or   2. where the AI system "generates or manipulates image, audio or video content constituting a deep fake", and/or   3. where the AI system "generates or manipulates text which is published with the purpose of informing the public on matters of public interest shall disclose that the text has been artificially generated or manipulated". threads.thread_title: The State Of AI in Business Communications
threads.thread_body: AI Notetakers and Communications was one of the topics discussed at the Sonoma Offsite last week. There was a lot of debate on the topic, so I wanted to share this benchmarking report on The State of AI in Business Communications. Enjoy!  Meeting & Communication AI Trends:   AI meeting assistants are going mainstream: Top features in demand include:   CRM integration (49%)   Real-time transcription (47%)   Automated call summaries (44%)   Voice-to-text & sentiment analysis (36-40%)   Voice analysis is hot: 81% plan to invest in AI for analyzing voice data within 12 months. Half already have clear strategies in place.   Executives are driving adoption: C-level execs are the most active users and champions of AI meeting tech (91% are leading voice AI adoption).   High ROI use cases: Voice data tools are linked to faster resolutions, fewer complaints, increased upsell opportunities, and lower agent burnout.   But… Security is a concern:   72% expect AI-generated fraud (e.g. deepfake voices) in the next year.   Yet, 31% of companies still haven't implemented fraud prevention tools.   Smaller orgs especially lack resources/confidence in detecting fraud.      The Bigger Picture:   97% of businesses expect to increase AI investment in the next 3-5 years.   Customer service and internal collaboration are the most common early applications.   AI is moving from automation -> augmentation--helping teams think, not just do.

threads.thread_title: How Are You Reporting Key Team Updates To Your GC?
threads.thread_body: In our legal department, we're split into 7 teams. We have weekly team leads meetings to flag anything relevant across teams, and then each lead also has regular 1:1s with the GC to go deeper on team-specific blockers or critical matters. That said, we're realizing these syncs just aren't enough time to cover everything the GC wants (or needs) visibility into. There's a lot happening across teams, and not all of it fits neatly into a weekly meeting or 1:1. On top of that, it's unrealistic to expect the GC to stay on top of every Jira task or dig through various team-level reports. We want to find a smarter, more consistent way to report what the GC should know - without creating more manual work for lawyers or overloading the GC with too much detail. We track most work in Jira, so I'm thinking of an automated weekly summary ("newsletter") based on tagged issues, status changes, and comments. But we also have projects tracked in Sheets, Docs, etc., so it's not all in one place. Has anyone found a good system or workflow to regularly surface the most important team updates to your GC - especially across tools and teams - in a way that's low-effort but high-signal? Would love any ideas or lessons learned.
